intro: Peucedanum vaginatum var. puberulum, commonly known as the pubescent cowparsley, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows and along stream banks. Its fruit is a dry, two-lobed schizocarp, which releases small, winged seeds when mature. The species is noted for its hairy foliage, which gives it its common name.
